licensingSteps.title: Complete 180 Hours of Pre-License Education
licensingSteps.desc: Take the 6 required 30-hour courses: Principles I & II, Law of Agency, Law of Contracts, Promulgated Contract Forms, and Real Estate Finance.

licensingSteps.title: File Your Application with TREC
licensingSteps.desc: Submit your application online using the TREC Online Services portal. The application fee is $205.

licensingSteps.title: Get Fingerprinted
licensingSteps.desc: Schedule a fingerprinting appointment with IdentoGO for your background check. The fee is typically around $38.25.

licensingSteps.title: Pass the Texas Real Estate Exam
licensingSteps.desc: Schedule your exam with Pearson VUE. The exam has 125 questions, and you must pass both the national and state portions.

licensingSteps.title: Find a Sponsoring Broker
licensingSteps.desc: You cannot practice real estate until your license is sponsored by an active Texas broker. Once sponsored, your license becomes active.

eligibility: Must be at least 18 years old
Must be a US citizen or lawfully admitted alien
Must reside in Texas (unless applying as out-of-state)
Must meet TREC's qualifications for honesty, trustworthiness, and integrity
educationExam: 180 hours of approved pre-license education (6 courses)
Pass Texas state exam (125 questions total)

exam.prepTip: The Texas exam has a ~56–60% first-time pass rate. Focus heavily on the National portion, which requires a higher percentage (66%) to pass than the State portion.

faqs.q: How much does it cost to get a real estate license in Texas?
faqs.a: The total cost is typically between $535 and $900. This includes the 180-hour pre-license course ($250–$600), the TREC application fee ($205), the fingerprinting fee ($38.25), and the state exam fee ($43).

faqs.q: How long does it take to get a Texas real estate license?
faqs.a: It typically takes 3 to 6 months. You must complete 180 classroom hours of education, which is significantly more than most other states.

faqs.q: What are the requirements for a Texas real estate license?
faqs.a: You must be at least 18 years old, a U.S. citizen or lawfully admitted alien, and a resident of Texas. You must complete 180 hours of education, submit an application, pass a background check, and pass the state exam.

faqs.q: Is the Texas real estate exam hard?
faqs.a: The exam is challenging, with a first-time pass rate around 56–60%. It consists of 125 questions, and you must pass both the National (56/85 correct) and State (21/40 correct) portions.

faqs.q: Can I take the Texas real estate courses online?
faqs.a: Yes, TREC approves many providers to offer the 180-hour pre-license coursework entirely online. Online courses allow you to study at your own pace.

faqs.q: How much do real estate agents make in Texas?
faqs.a: The average annual income for Texas real estate agents varies widely but typically ranges from $45,000 to $85,000. Top producers in major markets like Dallas or Austin can earn well over $150,000.

faqs.q: Do I need a college degree to be a real estate agent in Texas?
faqs.a: No, you do not need a college degree. However, you must complete the 180 hours of specific real estate education required by TREC.

faqs.q: Who is the exam provider for the Texas real estate exam?
faqs.a: Pearson VUE administers the Texas real estate sales agent exam. You will schedule your exam through their website after your application is approved by TREC.

faqs.q: What happens if I fail the Texas real estate exam?
faqs.a: If you fail one or both portions, you can retake the failed portion(s). You have three attempts within one year of filing your application. The retake fee is $43.

faqs.q: Can I get a Texas real estate license with a criminal record?
faqs.a: It depends on the offense. TREC evaluates each applicant's honesty, trustworthiness, and integrity. You can request a 'Fitness Determination' from TREC before applying to see if you would be eligible.
